Admissions applicants reach record hig
By JAY GOODGOLD
Hopkins has received more applications for admission this year
than ever before due to an intensified recruiting effort, Admissions Director Glen Thomas said
yesterday.
With the application deadline
officially past, over three thousand applications have been filed,
an increase over last year's previous high of about 2800.
The Admissions Office's longstanding effort to diversify its applicant pool in terms of academic
concentration also showed results
as students indicating a desire to
major in the Humanities increased roughly 33 per cent.
Engineering Sciences concen-

trates also showed a 33 per cent
increase while students expressing a preference for the Social
and Behavioral Sciences went up
about 20 per cent, as compared
to the overall 16 per cent _increase in applications.
The percentage of women applicants did not increase over last
year. Thomas said also that his
office has no figures on minority
applications as of now.
The Admissions Director attributed the upward surge in applicants in the three fields to the
University's participation in the
Student Search Survey, which enables more students in the nonNatural Sciences areas to receive
information about Hopkins.

"Because of the student survey
in these three fields we were able
to give good exposure for students who would not have
thought of Hopkins," Thomas
stated.
Quantitative Scierices exhibited an increase of only one person
to 97, while those students listed
in the undecided category declined by over 100.
Concerning the entire applicant pool, Thomas noted that
this year's increase is in part due
to an expanded travelling schedule by his office, as well as an
effort towards more personal
contact.
"Our traveling and visiting of
schools has had some effect. We

eyect a carryover effect into the
nekt 'few years. We've also tried
to Make' our contact with students more -personal this years"
"There's been a riatiOnwide
trend this year in application to
all of the more selective schools
in the country," Thomas said.
Since September, Thomas and
his staff have travelled extensively, especially in the Western United States. As a result, applications from Arizona, California,
Colorado and New Mexico went
up by 18 to 88.
California and Colorado accounted for the majority of the
rise, with the latter showing the
greatest change with 22 applications, twelve more than the 1974
total.
Natural Sciences showed an increase with a net gain of over 130
as did pre-med applicants, whose
total is approximately 1600.
Despite the increase in the
Natural Sciences, Thomas expects to accept a large percentage
of Humanities, Engineering, and
Social and Behavioral Sciences
majors, mainly due to the "improved quality of the applicant
field."
Thomas termed this year's
group "the best group Hopkins
has had."

AC reviews SC Academic Reports
By ALAN HIRSCH
The Academic Council reviewed the Student Council's Academic Reports at a special meeting Tuesday evening, where the
members "filtered out" the portions they believed invalid or inaccurate, Dean of Arts and
Sciences George Owen disclosed.
The AC members screened the
Reports for sections that were
not valid, so that they can proceed now to utilize the Reports
in their evaluations of the departments, Owen said.
He stated that while the Reports have been, for the most
part, received favorably by the
faculty, several department chairmen have complained of inaccuracies in the Reports, stemming
largely from the SC's failure to
make changes suggested by the
departments after the presentation of the Reports' initial drafts.
A number of department
chairmen have pointed out certain problems in the Reports resulting from their heavy reliance
on Teacher Evaluation (TEVAL)
data, the validity of which has
come under question.
"It's simply not scientific,"
said Philosophy Chairman Peter
Achinstein of the Reports.
"The evaluation of TEVAL
has always been troublesome. It
has all types of problems," commented Dr. Gordon Wolman,
Geography and Environmental
Engineering head.
"It's almost impossible to evaluate teaching by anyone," he
added.
Another department head,
English Chairman Ron'ald
Paulson, termed the Reports
"quite fair" with "just a few mistakes."
One change he recommended
after the initial draft—the elimination of a suggestion for more
writing courses since those are
the responsibility of the Writing
Seminars—was accepted and incorporated into the final draft of
the Reports, he said.
Paulson stated that the department is taking the Reports' rec-

ommendations seriously, and has
been deliberating on the recommendation to abolish requirements for upper level courses
since the Fall.
Owen noted that the primary
influence of the Reports will
come through their "persuasive
powers" and not through attempts by the SC to "legislate"
the recommendations to the faculty and administration.

He said that some bad feeling
on the part of faculty of certain
departments derives from the Reports' straightforward, often
blunt appraisals of individual professors.
The Dean also said that the unprecedented situation of undergraduates evaluating faculty has
been partially responsible for
some of the unfavorable reactions to the Reports.

CountyExec Venetoulis speaks in UGB series
By RICHARD LORRAINE
"The single biggest problem
that we have in this country is a
resurrection of people's reasonableness towards government."
This is indeed no small task for
the newly-elected Baltimore
County Executive, Ted Venetoulis.
Speaking in the first of the
Union Governing Board's series
of informal conversations with
prominent figures last night,
Venetoulis, who recently cornpleted his twelfth week in office,
admitted that he , frequently
spends "up to fourteen to eighteen hours a day"--in his office,
trying to accomplish this goal.
A man pushing the lower edges
of middle age, Venetoulis projects the image of a newcomer to
politics, eager to start the longneeded reformation of local government. He said he realizes,
however, that he is attempting to
overcome the triple disadvantage
of years of mismanagement, recent public cynicism towards
government, and often hostile
press.
"It's in the press itself," he declared. "The writers are cynical
and they ought to be cynical. In
Baltimore County, the press
missed the corruption completely. It took the Washington Post
to break the story of Baltimore
County corruption."
"Because of that," he stated,
"they " have tried with a vengeance to kind of catch up."
However, he acknowledged
that intensive interest in government, on the part of both the
public and the press, is necessary
ingredient in equitable
crovernment.

After a short declaration of
the aims and purposes of his adVenetoulis opened the floor to
questions from the audience.
One listener seized the opportunity to inquire about the recent defeat of Venetoulis' nominee for the office of County Administrator, Jim Reed. The decision created many political undercurrents in Baltimore County
administration. Venetoulis cited
himself as the political catalyst
which caused Reed's eventual rejection for this office by the
Baltimore County Council. He
said that by proposing a largescale urban-renewal program several weeks before 'the nomination, he had given a right-wing
minority the chance to coalesce
into a vocal political group.
Using this as a starting point,
Venetoulis then launched into an
animated discourse on the relationship between Baltimore
County administration and the
Council. "To me, the biggest
problem with the Council's behavior was that they violated a
traditional executive-legislative
relationship," he declared. "By
the violation, they caused great
grief to the county."
"I don't intend to let the
Council run the government," he
further asserted. "I would be violating my own sense of responsibility if I did that."
He did state, however, that
one heartening aspect of the incident was the appearance of voluminous editorial support of
Reed. He said this indicated that
there is an increasing positive attitude in the county, which he
expects to greatly aid him in his

program of reform.

Ted Venetoulis

In response to a question on
Baltimore County and Baltimore
City relationships, Venetoulis
stated that his administration
would seek greater cooperation
between the two governmental
structures than was previously
exhibited.
He used as an example for this
cooperation the problem of
dredging the Baltimore City harbor and depositing the sludge on
Hart Miller Island.
While he acknowledged the necessity of dredging the harbor to
preserve the economic base of
the city, as an avowed environmentalist Venetoulis is opposed
to the dumping of the residue at

that location. Even though he
was opposed to this action, he
was concerned enough about
County-City relationships that he
refused to participate on the panel reviewing the problem unless
Mayor Schaeffer of Baltimore City was also present.
After further inquiries, Venetoulis strongly asserted that he is
completely opposed to any form
of merger between the city and
county governments. He feels
that the main problem with government is that it is too centralized, bureaucratic, and unwieldy.
"Democracy assumes a certain
amount of inefficiency for the
running of government," he said.

For those of you who had been anticipating a student
referendum next week to finally put to rest the mounting
controversy of Honor Code versus proctoring, well, we've got
good news and we've got bad news.
The bad news is that you won't have to choose next week
between mandated proctoring and the University's 60 year
old Honor Code. The referendum has been delayed until
sometime in late April.
The good news is that the Student Council has launched a
new committee to further modify the proctoring proposal
given by the old committee, whose suggestion was
pronounced infeasible by those administrators affected by it.
During three weeks of deliberating and formulating a
proposal, the original committee failed to officially consult
Dean Sigmund Suskind before making public their
suggestion, which called for a major revision of the Dean's
current role in arbitrating academic offenses. Thus, upon the
Dean's disapproval, the panel had nothing to show for all its
extended deadlines and exhaustive investigation but an
untenable proposal.
Following the acknowledged "tactical blunder," the
Council voted this week to work the proposal into a form
acceptable to all concerned with the aid of a student-faculty
committee. We urge that this latest foray into the realm of
University policy be conducted with greater efficiency than
the previous one, and that the panel abandon the irrational
conviction that those affected by policy changes should not
be consulted about them.

semester, student interest in this important issue will wane to
a point that may threaten the validity of a full student vote.

By ANDREW WALDER
"Hearts and Minds",-a new movie on our Vietnam War (At the
Cerberus I Theater, M Street,
Georgetown), is more than just a
powerfully realistic documentary
—it is also a sobering reflection on
Americans and America. Without
employing a narrator, the producers, by splicing together interviews with Americans and
Vietnamese, along with clips of
speeches by American politicians
and extensive footage of killing
and bombing, have succeeded in
putting forward a powerful message about ill-founded American
attitudes and the destruction and
suffering they have caused (and are
still causing).
"Hearts and Minds" pulls no
punches—it literally numbs a viewer with a chilling account of what
this war means at a basic human
level. Napalmed children, their
charred skin hanging from their naked bodies, run screaming down a
dirt road away from their flaming
village. Several husky, fully equipped and uniformed G.I.'s take
turns 'interrogating' a skinny,
youthful Vietnamese (a VC?), who
is clad only in a shirt and shorts. In
this 'interrogation' the youth is
kicked repeatedly in the groin by
the booted soldiers, and through
the whole ordeal the frightened,
wincing youth's glazed eyes stare
straight into the camera.
Even more gripping are the interviews with peasants who lived
through American bombing raids.
An elderly, wrinkled woman relates that her home and village
were devastated by bombs from an

unseen plane (B-52). Gradually losing her composure, she explains
"My sister is dead...I have no
one...I have no home...nowhere to
go...nothing to do." Then, for an
interminable sixty seconds, she just
cries.
Show It To Your President
The attitudes of the Vietnamese
about the war come across eqully
clear. A South Vietnamese business
executive explains how he is planning to capitalize on the economic
"take-off" that will occur as soon
as the military situation stabilizes.
It seems that other sectors of
Vietnamese society have different
perspectives, however. A Saigon
shopkeeper confides—"The prcrblem is American imperialism—this
is a war for national independence." A warehouse worker in the
South explains that the Saigon government is the biggest obstacle to
peace, and that the people are
afraid to speak out against it. A
Catholic priest puts the situation a
bit differently—the Thieu regime is
the opponent of peace and justice.
They arrest and torture those who
speak out for peace and freedom,
and brand them as communists. In
doing so, they are defeating themselves, for they are teaching people
that the communists are the forces
of peace and justice.
A peasant in the North is far less
analytical. He explains that his village is isolated, and irately asks the
cameraman why the Americans
have bombed it. He points to a pile
of rubble, and reveals that the bodies of his wife and daughter lie
there. His voice cracking, he points
to another spot, saying that his

eight-year-old daughter was feeding
the pigs there when the bombs •
struck. She died instantly. The
man's voice rises and breaks. He
walks in circles, gesticulating wildly and raving at the camera-man.
"What have we done to you
Americans? Do we bomb your children?".. He begins to sob as he
picks a tattered shirt out of the
rubble. "Here—this was my daughter's shirt. Look at it...take it back
to America...show it to your president...throw it in Nixon's face...
(screaming)...tell him he is the
murderer of little girls!"
Not only are Vietnamese attitudes revealed, but American attitudes are also given their fair share
of time. These are the attitudes
that make senseless devastation
possible. An Air Force pilot relates
the satisfaction he feels upon completing a successful bombing mission. He sees himself not as a killer
but as a 'skilled technician'. A father of a dead Vietnam vet, when
asked if he felt if his son's death
was for a worthwhile cause, replies: "Americans are taught to
obey their government. When we
are called upon, we have an obliga-

tion to obey. I believe in our President...I believe he did what he had
to do..." John Foster Dulles reveals
that communism is a growing cancer that must be halted before it
spreads. But a young co-ed demurs,
explaining: "I'm only interested in
what affects me the most".
Scene: a coffin is draped with a
South Vietnamese flag. Two young
boys stand in front of it, wailing,
one holding a portrait of his dead
father in his hands, the other beating his fists and head upon the coffin. Their mother stands by, sobbing quietly. Six military pall-bearers pick up the coffin and carry it
out to a field. The children wail
even more loudly, following closely and looking alternately at their
father's portrait and the coffin. As
the box is lowered into the grave,
the mother breaks down, wailing
and talking incoherently, and tries
to climb into the grave with her
dead husband. She struggles with
the pall-bearers who pull her out of
the gave, and finally gives up, staring silently at the dirt being
thrown over the casket.
Next Scene: the edge of a peaceful lake. General Westmoreland,

commander of the U.S. forces
from 1964-68, explains smugly:
"You have to understand...the
Oriental does not place as high a
value on human life as we do."
The message of the film is.conveyed in the final few scenes
—Americans have tried hard not to
learn from their Vietnam experience.
...A parade. A banner proclaiming "Citizens for Victory in
Vietnam". Hardhats, tatoos, boy
scouts, American flags. On the
sidewalk,jeering—the VVAW. Pickets declaring "Peace Without Honor". The paraders turn and sneer at
the pickets. They swear at them
and flip them the bird. The police
move in, violence ensues, bloodied
protesters are hauled into police
wagons. One of the protesting veterans avoids the police and seeks
out the camera amidst the confusion. "What the hell is this?", he
pleads, "We were there, we fought
there, we know what it's all about.
Why won't they listen?"
"Hearts and Minds" deserves
more than the academy award it
has been nominated for—it deserves to be seen.

system assignment of vacant spaces in these facilities will be accomplished in the
fairest possible manner.

these two buildings for the 1975/76 academic year. Each one.of the seven lottery

available at three locations: Housing Office in Wolman Hall, Office of Residential
Life in the Alumni Memorial Residences, and the Dean of Students Office in the
Hopkins Union. Each packetcontains an information sheet outlining the procedures
governing the lottery and 'official' lottery cards to be used for participation in the lottery.

Wolman Hall and Rogers House should be directed to the Housing Office.

By ANDREW WALDER
"Hearts and Minds",-a new movie on our Vietnam War (At the
Cerberus I Theater, M Street,
Georgetown), is more than just a
powerfully realistic documentary
—it is also a sobering reflection on
Americans and America. Without
employing a narrator, the producers, by splicing together interviews with Americans and
Vietnamese, along with clips of
speeches by American politicians
and extensive footage of killing
and bombing, have succeeded in
putting forward a powerful message about ill-founded American
attitudes and the destruction and
suffering they have caused (and are
still causing).
"Hearts and Minds" pulls no
punches—it literally numbs a viewer with a chilling account of what
this war means at a basic human
level. Napalmed children, their
charred skin hanging from their naked bodies, run screaming down a
dirt road away from their flaming
village. Several husky, fully equipped and uniformed G.I.'s take
turns 'interrogating' a skinny,
youthful Vietnamese (a VC?), who
is clad only in a shirt and shorts. In
this 'interrogation' the youth is
kicked repeatedly in the groin by
the booted soldiers, and through
the whole ordeal the frightened,
wincing youth's glazed eyes stare
straight into the camera.
Even more gripping are the interviews with peasants who lived
through American bombing raids.
An elderly, wrinkled woman relates that her home and village
were devastated by bombs from an

unseen plane (B-52). Gradually losing her composure, she explains
"My sister is dead...I have no
one...I have no home...nowhere to
go...nothing to do." Then, for an
interminable sixty seconds, she just
cries.
Show It To Your President
The attitudes of the Vietnamese
about the war come across eqully
clear. A South Vietnamese business
executive explains how he is planning to capitalize on the economic
"take-off" that will occur as soon
as the military situation stabilizes.
It seems that other sectors of
Vietnamese society have different
perspectives, however. A Saigon
shopkeeper confides—"The prcrblem is American imperialism—this
is a war for national independence." A warehouse worker in the
South explains that the Saigon government is the biggest obstacle to
peace, and that the people are
afraid to speak out against it. A
Catholic priest puts the situation a
bit differently—the Thieu regime is
the opponent of peace and justice.
They arrest and torture those who
speak out for peace and freedom,
and brand them as communists. In
doing so, they are defeating themselves, for they are teaching people
that the communists are the forces
of peace and justice.
A peasant in the North is far less
analytical. He explains that his village is isolated, and irately asks the
cameraman why the Americans
have bombed it. He points to a pile
of rubble, and reveals that the bodies of his wife and daughter lie
there. His voice cracking, he points
to another spot, saying that his

eight-year-old daughter was feeding
the pigs there when the bombs •
struck. She died instantly. The
man's voice rises and breaks. He
walks in circles, gesticulating wildly and raving at the camera-man.
"What have we done to you
Americans? Do we bomb your children?".. He begins to sob as he
picks a tattered shirt out of the
rubble. "Here—this was my daughter's shirt. Look at it...take it back
to America...show it to your president...throw it in Nixon's face...
(screaming)...tell him he is the
murderer of little girls!"
Not only are Vietnamese attitudes revealed, but American attitudes are also given their fair share
of time. These are the attitudes
that make senseless devastation
possible. An Air Force pilot relates
the satisfaction he feels upon completing a successful bombing mission. He sees himself not as a killer
but as a 'skilled technician'. A father of a dead Vietnam vet, when
asked if he felt if his son's death
was for a worthwhile cause, replies: "Americans are taught to
obey their government. When we
are called upon, we have an obliga-

tion to obey. I believe in our President...I believe he did what he had
to do..." John Foster Dulles reveals
that communism is a growing cancer that must be halted before it
spreads. But a young co-ed demurs,
explaining: "I'm only interested in
what affects me the most".
Scene: a coffin is draped with a
South Vietnamese flag. Two young
boys stand in front of it, wailing,
one holding a portrait of his dead
father in his hands, the other beating his fists and head upon the coffin. Their mother stands by, sobbing quietly. Six military pall-bearers pick up the coffin and carry it
out to a field. The children wail
even more loudly, following closely and looking alternately at their
father's portrait and the coffin. As
the box is lowered into the grave,
the mother breaks down, wailing
and talking incoherently, and tries
to climb into the grave with her
dead husband. She struggles with
the pall-bearers who pull her out of
the gave, and finally gives up, staring silently at the dirt being
thrown over the casket.
Next Scene: the edge of a peaceful lake. General Westmoreland,

commander of the U.S. forces
from 1964-68, explains smugly:
"You have to understand...the
Oriental does not place as high a
value on human life as we do."
The message of the film is.conveyed in the final few scenes
—Americans have tried hard not to
learn from their Vietnam experience.
...A parade. A banner proclaiming "Citizens for Victory in
Vietnam". Hardhats, tatoos, boy
scouts, American flags. On the
sidewalk,jeering—the VVAW. Pickets declaring "Peace Without Honor". The paraders turn and sneer at
the pickets. They swear at them
and flip them the bird. The police
move in, violence ensues, bloodied
protesters are hauled into police
wagons. One of the protesting veterans avoids the police and seeks
out the camera amidst the confusion. "What the hell is this?", he
pleads, "We were there, we fought
there, we know what it's all about.
Why won't they listen?"
"Hearts and Minds" deserves
more than the academy award it
has been nominated for—it deserves to be seen.

The Housing Office has adopted a proposal by the Housing Committee

regarding the creation of a lottery system began in April of last year. Much time
and effort has gone into the development of the lottery. It is felt that through this
system assignment of vacant spaces in these facilities will be accomplished in the
fairest possible manner.

these two buildings for the 1975/76 academic year. Each one.of the seven lottery

apartment in each building. Lottery drawings will be held over a period of 8 days
allowing those students not selected in one drawing the opportunity to decide whether

be held Monday, March 17, 1975.

available at three locations: Housing Office in Wolman Hall, Office of Residential

Hopkins Union. Each packetcontains an information sheet outlining the procedures
governing the lottery and 'official' lottery cards to be used for participation in the lottery.

Wolman Hall and Rogers House should be directed to the Housing Office.
